componenttext: All right. Fair enough. I'm just noting this is first time, I mean, you've been asked about it before, but it's the first time you've come out and raised that flag. Second question I had was you did quite a few projects in 2015, adding bev can plants, aerosol, all kinds of stuff. How should we think about the phasing as we work through '16? Or how would we think about quantifying, if it's possible? What the impact will be as you start to get results from that all your hard work?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question. I'll -- as best trying to answer that. When you think about the projects we've talked about even on this call, let's start with Monterray, Mexico, it started up this month. And so, as you know, there's always a learning curve
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question. I'll -- as best trying to answer that. When you think about the projects we've talked about even on this call, let's start with Monterray, Mexico, it started up this month. And so, as you know, there's always a learning curve there, and Scott said we'd have a little bit of start-up costs. So I would expect to kind of the typical learning curve and something like this is 3 to 6 months. And so I think, as we get to certainly the second half of the year, maybe even a little second quarter, we'll start to see the benefit of that. And then we're going to get additional leverage as we put the second line on that's going to be starting up kind of second -- late second, early third quarter. So you can hopefully see a trajectory there. In the fourth quarter last year, we started the new line in devices in the U.K. and the impact extruded line. We started up the India plant. Anytime you start a new plant, the learning curve is a little bit longer than just adding existing line or new lines into existing facilities. So I think that devices we feel pretty good about in terms of getting results out of that sooner rather than later. I think the India one is going to be a little bit longer. The Lublin, Poland we talked about that we -- as we continue to ramp up the end production there, we should see some benefit as time goes on. But it does -- it's a ramp-up starting in early '16 as we go forward with that. And we talked about the contour. And in fact I know the last couple of quarters, we talked about the contour bottle as well as the G3. It's on the -- We're making commercially -- commercial product right now. It's on the shelves right now. So we have high expectations as we go into 2016 that you're going to see some momentum there. All of that leads to exactly what Scott was saying that in the first quarter, we still have some start-up costs, and we're really not getting a lot of the benefits, but we're gaining momentum each month we go by in year 2016.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Ball Corporation Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Thursday, January 28, 2016.I would now like to turn to co
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Ball Corporation Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Thursday, January 28, 2016.
I would now like to turn to conference over to John Hayes, CEO. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Tia, and good morning, everyone. This is Ball Corporation's conference call regarding the company's fourth quarter and full year 2015 results.The information provided during this call will contain forward-looking statements. Actual res
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Tia, and good morning, everyone. This is Ball Corporation's conference call regarding the company's fourth quarter and full year 2015 results.
The information provided during this call will contain forward-looking statements. Actual results or outcomes may differ materially from those that may be expressed or implied. Some factors that could cause the results or outcomes to differ are in the company's latest 10-K and in other company SEC filings as well as the company news releases. Now if you don't already have our earnings release, it's available on our website at ball.com.
Information regarding the use of non-GAAP financial measures may also be found on our website. With regard to Ball's proposed offer for Rexam and consistent with the requirements of the U.K. Takeover Code, we will limit our comments regarding the transaction to: number one, what has already been made public via the 2/7 release; number two, where we are in the regulatory process; and number three, an update of ongoing economic hedging and debt activities related to the proposed transaction.
Also note that there may be limitations regarding the depth of our business commentary as well as our future outlook, and certain other items we would normally discuss on an earnings conference call due to the nature of the proposed transaction and restrictions under the U.K Takeover Code.
Given the nature of our proposed offer, today's issued press release, webcast and conference call are advertisements and should not be considered a prospectus. Investors should not make any investment decision in relation to the new Ball shares issued in connection with the Rexam transaction, except on the basis of information in the prospectus and the Scheme Documents, which are proposed to be published in due course. This presentation and transcription of comments are not for release in whole or in part in, into or from any jurisdiction or to do so would constitute a violation of the relevant laws of such jurisdiction. For more information on Ball's proposed acquisition of Rexam, please visit the offer for Rexam page on ball.com.
Now joining me on the call today is Scott Morrison, Senior Vice President and our Chief Financial Officer. I'll provide a brief overview of our company's performance, Scott will discuss financial and global packaging metrics and then I'll finish up with comments on our aerospace business and the outlook for 2016.
Our fourth quarter volumes, free cash flow and results from operations were in line with our expectations. The headwinds we acknowledged throughout 2015 around earnings translation, project start-up costs and tough volume comps in our North American food continued, while others like aluminum premium became a tailwind and a lower effective tax rate aided the quarter. Overall, however, we are pleased with the performance of our businesses. And Scott will go into more detail on the quarter and full year in just a moment.
Since we spoke last October, we've made notable progress to strategically and operationally position Ball for the future, including successfully beginning the production of beverage can ends in our existing Lublin, Poland facility, which is also slated for additional end modules in 2016. The successful start-up of our Monterrey, Mexico beverage can and end facility, which is serving multiple foreign brewers importing their product into the U.S. The successful start-up of a new aluminum impact extruded line in devices U.K. as well as our recently announced aluminum impact extruded aerosol expansion in Velim, Czech Republic, which is expected to come online in early 2017.
The successful start-up of our new aluminum impact extruded aerosol facility in India, various investments to further the growth of our specialty can and new product portfolio, including our new contour bottle line in Conroe, Texas; and our new tinplate aerosol technology in Chestnut Hill, Tennessee; and the continued construction of our new beverage can plant in Myanmar now slated to open in April 2016.
We also completed the acquisition of the remaining interest in our Brazilian joint venture and received conditional regulatory approvals for our proposed offer for Rexam from the European Commission and Brazilian CADE. Discussions are ongoing with the FTC.
We have weathered a very busy 2015 in terms of managing the headwinds, investing in our future and making progress with our Rexam acquisition. Everyone at our company has been extremely busy. And I want to thank everyone at Ball who has persevered and risen to the challenge. Thanks.
And with that, I'll turn it over to Scott for a review of our fourth quarter numbers.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Ball's comparable diluted earnings per share for fourth quarter 2015 were $0.80 versus last year's $0.84. And for the full year 2015, comparable diluted earnings per share were $3.48 versus $3.88 in 2014. Fourth quarter and full year compara
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Ball's comparable diluted earnings per share for fourth quarter 2015 were $0.80 versus last year's $0.84. And for the full year 2015, comparable diluted earnings per share were $3.48 versus $3.88 in 2014. Fourth quarter and full year comparable diluted earnings per share were unfavorably impacted by a net $0.04 and $0.49, respectively, related to foreign currency effects, start-up costs and other one-time items.
As John alluded to, the following factors contributed to results in the fourth quarter: $0.06 of unfavorable currency translation effects largely due to a weaker euro; $0.02 of start-up costs associated with capital projects and aluminum premium tailwind of $0.04.
Year 2015 free cash flow came in at $558 million after $528 million of CapEx and excluding roughly $80 million of cash costs associated with the Rexam transaction.
Our GAAP results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015 were unfavorably impacted by the economic hedges we put in place to reduce currency exchange rate exposure associated with the British pound denominated cash portion of the announced acquisition price for Rexam and to mitigate exposure to interest rate changes associated with anticipated debt issuances, also in connection with the cash portion of the proposed transaction. These economic hedges allow us to lock in transaction's purchase price economics, though they will likely continue to cause disruption to quarterly GAAP earnings. Details on these economic hedges are provided in Note 2 of today's earnings release.
Credit quality and liquidity of the company remains very solid with comparable EBIT to interest coverage at 5.6x and net debt to comparable EBITDA at 2.5x, including the noncurrent restricted cash sitting in escrow from the December U.S. and euro bond placements. The company has enough committed credit and available liquidity at year-end to consummate the proposed Rexam transaction and provide ongoing liquidity for the company.
For a complete summary of fourth quarter and full year 2015 results on a GAAP and non-GAAP basis and details regarding the fourth quarter and full year, please refer to the notes section of today's earnings release, which includes a simplified table format summarizing business consolidation activities.
Now moving to operations. Our metal beverage Americas and Asia segment comparable operating earnings for fourth quarter and full year 2015 were down slightly year-over-year, mainly due to unfavorable pricing in China, slightly lower performance in Brazil and project start-up costs in North America. Segment volumes in the quarter were up approximately 5% and just up over 1% for the full year 2015.
Our Monterrey, Mexico can plant just begun producing cans and ends earlier this month. Our second can line will come up mid-year. In China, while volumes remain relatively healthy, the overall pricing environment remains extremely challenging, and our aggressive cost out programs have not been able to keep up with the price erosion and we expect to be down in profitability again in 2016 in this region.
European beverage comparable earnings were up nicely in the quarter due to aluminum premium tailwinds of EUR 6 million as well as improved plant utilization for the full year. Comparable earnings were down approximately $20 million to unfavorable foreign earnings translation. On a constant currency basis, they were up year-over-year. Low single-digit volume growth and low double-digit specialty can growth continue to reflect the ongoing value-added benefits of the can with European consumers.
Food and household comparable segment earnings were down in the quarter, as segment volumes declined following the customer shift in U.S. food cans as well as manufacturing inefficiencies. Excluding the customer shift, our food can volumes were down slightly in the fourth quarter due to the earlier conclusion of the pack late in the third quarter, but up for the full year.
For the fourth quarter and full year, the segment was also impacted by unfavorable earnings translation related to the European portion of the extruded aluminum aerosol business and start-up costs related to numerous capital projects across the segment. Our next-generation lightweight steel aerosol can manufacturing technology is now commercially available on shelves, and further growth in our global extruded aluminum businesses as well as significantly better operating performance in our tinplate businesses will provide good opportunity to improve segment performance in 2016.
In summary, our global packaging businesses are extremely focused on driving EVA dollars from our new capital projects. To employees listening in on today's call, thank you for all the great work during what has been one of the busiest times in our company's 136-year history.
Now as we look to 2016, reflecting Ball, as a stand-alone company today, here's a snapshot of some key financial metrics. We expect free cash flow to be in a similar range as 2015, excluding cash cost related to the Rexam transaction, with CapEx expected to be in the range of $400 million and working capital expected to be generally flat year-over-year. Interest expense is expected to be roughly $145 million, excluding debt refinancing and other costs. The full year effective tax rate on comparable earnings is expected to be in the range of 25%.
Corporate undistributed is to be expected to be in the range of $75 million, a year-over-year reduction of $17 million. Also recall that due to the acquisition of our JV's partners interest in Brazil, our outstanding shares at the beginning of this year are higher by 5.7 million shares, and we will no longer have any effects from this business in our noncontrolling interest line on the income statement. We expect our dividend to remain unchanged from its current level during the proposed acquisition process.
In 2016, we expect all of our segments to be up on a full year basis with the exception of China beverage can business. And while we expect the first quarter to be relatively soft through the repricing of our contracts in China, challenging comps in our food and household products business and the close out of start-up expenses in our various capital projects, momentum will accelerate as we move through the years.
One final heads-up before I turn it over to John. As we look to the successful closing of the Rexam transaction, we currently plan to incorporate into our future comments a focus on cash, earnings per share due to large about of intangible amortization we expect to record for the Rexam transaction.
And with that, I'll turn it back to you, John.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Scott. Our aerospace business reported a solid quarter, given the difficult comps they were up against. Contracted backlog held steady ending the quarter at $617 million. More exciting, however, is what is in front of us. Over the past few
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Scott. Our aerospace business reported a solid quarter, given the difficult comps they were up against. Contracted backlog held steady ending the quarter at $617 million. More exciting, however, is what is in front of us. Over the past few months, our aerospace business has won a variety of classified and nonclassified programs that are worth over $800 million that have not yet been booked into our backlog, as the contracts need to be signed and in several cases the funding needs to be approved by the U.S. government.
In addition, we still have a number of additional proposals submitted for award that collectively measure in the billions. A terrific job done by our folks, and we continue to be amazed by the creativity, agility and patience that they have shown. The near-term goals for the aerospace team are to finish strong on existing programs and ramp successfully on the new work throughout the second half of 2016.
Now turning to the future. We continue to make progress on our proposed offer for Rexam, and we look forward to reaping the benefits of growth capital deployed in 2015 to improve performance as well as the higher EVA dollar generation that these important investments will provide.
While our biggest challenge is to weather the unsustainable pricing environment in our China beverage can business, overall, we feel good about where we are. Our objectives are consistent with last year: successfully execute our capital projects, generate strong free cash flow, grow our specialty businesses, focus on cost optimization and manufacturing performance and cross the finish line on the proposed offer for Rexam.
Together, we are working hard to improve Ball in 2016 and beyond, and we look forward to a successful year ahead.
And with that, Tia, we're ready for questions.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] First question is from the line of Ghansham Panjabi from Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] First question is from the line of Ghansham Panjabi from Baird.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, since you last reported, one of your competitors announced that they're adding the first new metal beverage can plant in the U.S. since 1993. How do you view this announcement for the industry, first off? And does this impact your strategy in any way
componenttext: Hey, since you last reported, one of your competitors announced that they're adding the first new metal beverage can plant in the U.S. since 1993. How do you view this announcement for the industry, first off? And does this impact your strategy in any way as it relates to how optimized your production footprint is between standard and specialty cans in the U.S?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's -- obviously, we're aware of that, Ghansham, and I can't comment on the thought process around that. I can tell you the specialty can continue to grow strongly and that they are probably just trying to keep up with their own demand. I can tell yo
componenttext: No, it's -- obviously, we're aware of that, Ghansham, and I can't comment on the thought process around that. I can tell you the specialty can continue to grow strongly and that they are probably just trying to keep up with their own demand. I can tell you from our perspective that our system is in good shape. We continue to grow specialty containers off a relatively high base already. And we're trying to manage the 12-ounce capacity. And what I mean by that is, for example, in the last quarter or so, we've actually converted a line from 12-ounce into the specialty containers, and we've been just following that strategy we've been embarking on for a number of years now.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just, I guess, my second question related to Rexam, understanding the sensitivity around that, but just given the specific divestiture concessions for both Europe and Brazil that you've announced, how should we think about the buckets of synergi
componenttext: Okay. And just, I guess, my second question related to Rexam, understanding the sensitivity around that, but just given the specific divestiture concessions for both Europe and Brazil that you've announced, how should we think about the buckets of synergies that you outlined outside of the deal? I think you previously announced -- outlined 44% G&A, 22% freight, et cetera. Should we expect a different weighting going forward based on what you know now?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Scott. I wouldn't change the buckets too much. All that stuff will move around once you get to the closing, and we'll be able to give you a lot more clarity about that. But for right now, we're not updating what those changes might be.
componenttext: This is Scott. I wouldn't change the buckets too much. All that stuff will move around once you get to the closing, and we'll be able to give you a lot more clarity about that. But for right now, we're not updating what those changes might be.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ghansham, this is John. As I mentioned in my prepared remarks, due to U.K. Takeover Code and some of the rules and restrictions behind -- around it, we're just not in a position to comment any further than we have.
componenttext: Yes. Ghansham, this is John. As I mentioned in my prepared remarks, due to U.K. Takeover Code and some of the rules and restrictions behind -- around it, we're just not in a position to comment any further than we have.

componenttext: Nothing other than saying that we're in discussions and that we have said in our earnings release, we expect to close the transaction in the first half. And most likely, it's probably going to be in the second quarter of 2016. That's what we expect as we sit here today.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. Is it also -- just as a follow-on. Is it possible to get any color on bev can volumes and mix over in Europe in the fourth quarter and what you're expecting in '16?
componenttext: Okay, all right. Is it also -- just as a follow-on. Is it possible to get any color on bev can volumes and mix over in Europe in the fourth quarter and what you're expecting in '16?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm happy to go through that. Remember, fourth quarter is a seasonally slow quarter. So I'll just -- I'll start with that. I think, overall, the market in the fourth quarter was down slightly and we were down a little bit more. Most of our decline ha
componenttext: Yes, I'm happy to go through that. Remember, fourth quarter is a seasonally slow quarter. So I'll just -- I'll start with that. I think, overall, the market in the fourth quarter was down slightly and we were down a little bit more. Most of our decline had to do with actually exports. I think on a Continental Europe basis, we are right in line with the market. Some of those exports that we had into Africa as well as to the Middle East were a little bit slower. But again, I don't read into that much at all because it was the fourth quarter, which is always seasonally slow. I will point out and I have -- we've talked about this in the past that 2016 is an even numbered year. And typically, even numbered year, there are many events, including the World Cup, including the various soccer matches that usually show a little bit better than the odd years. And so we're coming off an odd year, where the overall market, as well as Ball, was up about 2%. So kind of in line with what our expectations. So depending on weather and depending on some other things, I think 2016, we see the same trends continue in Europe with growth in the beverage can at the expense of returnable glass and other substrates.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And can I get you to make kind of some of the same comments just around Latin America. I think with all the difficult economic conditions down in Brazil, but at the same time, we've got the Olympics coming up down there, any thoughts about that in t
componenttext: Okay. And can I get you to make kind of some of the same comments just around Latin America. I think with all the difficult economic conditions down in Brazil, but at the same time, we've got the Olympics coming up down there, any thoughts about that in the entire region in '16?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's interesting. As you all know, the first half of 2015, we were cycling off some very difficult comps from the World Cup in '14. And what we saw was it was relatively soft in the first half. And then the second half in Brazil picked up nicely. In
componenttext: Yes, it's interesting. As you all know, the first half of 2015, we were cycling off some very difficult comps from the World Cup in '14. And what we saw was it was relatively soft in the first half. And then the second half in Brazil picked up nicely. In the fourth quarter, I know the overall market was up 6%. We were up a bit more than that. I think a lot of the trends that we talked about in the past continue. Meaning, that the can continues to take share from other substrates in the beer category. I think specialty growth is occurring at a faster rate than standard containers. We are almost at -- not quite, but almost at a 50-50 mix between standard and specialty down in Brazil. And as we go into 2016, yes, there is a lot of political uncertainty and economic uncertainty. But the facts have not shown that the beverage can has been hurting. People are still eating. People are still drinking. And I think while the Olympics in Rio was a help, people have to remember, it is only just the Rio region, but that's a very dense populated -- densely populated area. So I think it should be beneficial. So as we sit here today, we're not expecting large growth in Brazil. But the can is holding up very well relative to other substrates and relative to other industries.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, both of those statements are correct. I mean, if you think about, '15 was a year of a lot of headwinds. We expect most of those headwinds to dissipate as we go into '16. Currency will have less of an impact. We'll have less start-up costs. We'll hav
componenttext: Well, both of those statements are correct. I mean, if you think about, '15 was a year of a lot of headwinds. We expect most of those headwinds to dissipate as we go into '16. Currency will have less of an impact. We'll have less start-up costs. We'll have a little bit in the first quarter, but then that should dissipate. And some of the one-time things we experienced in '15, we don't expect to experience again in '16, so.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think, the only other thing from a cash flow perspective, as we kind of pointed out there, we expect working capital will be relatively flat. So it's not a net inflow of cash. But we're going to have lower CapEx as well. And we'll probably have some
componenttext: And I think, the only other thing from a cash flow perspective, as we kind of pointed out there, we expect working capital will be relatively flat. So it's not a net inflow of cash. But we're going to have lower CapEx as well. And we'll probably have some pension funding and other things year-over-year that may be helps address the bridge you're trying to create.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. How much is pension of funding 2016 versus 2015?
componenttext: Okay. How much is pension of funding 2016 versus 2015?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, '15, we had less -- a little less than $20 million globally of pension funding. And in '16, we expect that number to be closer to $50 million of funding. And expense will be down about $7 million year-over-year.
componenttext: Yes, '15, we had less -- a little less than $20 million globally of pension funding. And in '16, we expect that number to be closer to $50 million of funding. And expense will be down about $7 million year-over-year.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. When I look at the North American metal food and household business, I mean, the margins have been up fairly nicely this year from an EBIT perspective. I assume that part of that was because you got rid of some lower margin business with the custome
componenttext: Okay. When I look at the North American metal food and household business, I mean, the margins have been up fairly nicely this year from an EBIT perspective. I assume that part of that was because you got rid of some lower margin business with the customer transition. But is there possibility for more margin improvement within metal food and household as we move into 2016 just as you don't have to take a lot of that capacity out of the system in 2016 and you've got plants and end-making facilities in the right locations at this point in time?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me kind of give a little different perspective, because I think about absolute EBIT in that business. And the loss of the announced customer contracts obviously hurt, but also, and Scott mentioned, continued manufacturing inefficiencies and a lit
componenttext: Yes, let me kind of give a little different perspective, because I think about absolute EBIT in that business. And the loss of the announced customer contracts obviously hurt, but also, and Scott mentioned, continued manufacturing inefficiencies and a little bit start-up hurt as well. As we go in 2016, we continue to look at rightsizing our fixed cost, and we're going to be accelerating those efforts in 2016 because while our margins were up, you're correct, the overall profitability wasn't where we hope or expected. So we have a lot of programs in place to drive those earnings back to where we think should be normalized.

componenttext: In Americas and Asia bev, I think you indicated segment volumes were up 5%. I'm wondering is it possible to parse that out between U.S., Latin America and Asia. And then just on Monterrey, if you could give us a little more color. It sounds like the first line is fully contracted out and running. I'm just wondering, can you confirm the second line is contracted out as well?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me hit that first. Yes, we can, and it's going to be up and running as we said to kind of a little bit later on this year, kind of 3 to 5 months after the start-up of the first line. So call it, late second quarter, early third quarter is a good way t
componenttext: Let me hit that first. Yes, we can, and it's going to be up and running as we said to kind of a little bit later on this year, kind of 3 to 5 months after the start-up of the first line. So call it, late second quarter, early third quarter is a good way to think about it. Getting back to your volume question. In North America, we were -- we're actually up a little bit in the fourth quarter. Some of it driven by continued directly backfilling some of the Monterrey, Mexico volume that you had just referred to as well as continued decent growth on the beer side of the category. In Brazil, we were up nicely in the fourth quarter. And even in Asia, even though we put new capital in there, our folks have been able to squeeze out a fair amount of new capacity with our existing asset base and we were up about 10% or so in China as well. So overall, it was good volume growth in that segment.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay, that's helpful. And then just following up on Scott's questions on food and household. I guess, segment earnings were down $45 million roughly from 2014 to 2015. Given the new capital projects you put in place, is it possible to frame how much
componenttext: Okay, okay, that's helpful. And then just following up on Scott's questions on food and household. I guess, segment earnings were down $45 million roughly from 2014 to 2015. Given the new capital projects you put in place, is it possible to frame how much of that you may be able to make up in 2016? I mean, is it half of it or most of it? Or could you even potentially exceed 2014 earnings levels in a really good year? Or just how should we think about kind of the earnings recovery potential in food and household in '16?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. Why don't I take it. I think, as we said earlier in 2015, there's not -- no short-term solutions to some of the issues here. But we expected to be up meaningfully. Can we get back to the height of that profitably? Over time, we expect to, ye
componenttext: This is John. Why don't I take it. I think, as we said earlier in 2015, there's not -- no short-term solutions to some of the issues here. But we expected to be up meaningfully. Can we get back to the height of that profitably? Over time, we expect to, yes. But it's not going to be happening in 1 year. It's probably a 2- to 3- to 4-year program depending on how the end markets shake out. But recall, let me give you a couple of drivers of some of that stuff. We have -- on the aerosol side of tinplate, we have a new G3 technology that's out that Scott mentioned is on the shelf right now. Number 2, in terms of overall aluminum aerosol growth, that continues to grow well. Just to give you a sense, in 2015, we were up on a global basis in aluminum aerosol about 5%, 6%. So that's good news. And we're going to continue to drive that. And our business is performing there. And then we got to get these manufacturing inefficiencies in our food can business in line.

componenttext: Yes, and the other thing I might add is, recall on the October call, we talked about we had some out of pattern freight in the third quarter because our Oss, Netherlands facility had come on stream, but not on stream in time to really have the high summer season. And so as we went into a more slower season, we were able to balance out the footprint a bit better and get rid of some of that out of pattern freight and cost.

So right now, as far as I can see forward in '16, that's the number.

componenttext: No, we'll talk about both. Our focus is always on file to cash. And so I just want to give people a heads-up that with this transaction, there'll be a fair amount of amortization. We'll talk about both. But we'll -- our focus is on generating cash flow. And so some of the accounting losses some of the context of the cash. And to me, the cash is the important part. So we'll give you both numbers.

componenttext: And just 2 more. Pension expense, I think, you mentioned it would be down to $7 million in '16. Is that related to an accounting change? And did you make an accounting change similar to what other companies have been doing?

componenttext: No, we did not. That's just some things we did last year in terms of some buyouts of closed plans and some of the changes in the interest rate assumptions, both on the discount rate and then the return on asset assumptions. So the combination of all those factors led to that $7 million decrease. We didn't change anything else fundamentally.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Most of that difference is the noncash business consolidation costs that gets added back. And the pension funding difference -- I'm sorry, on the other line, yes, the pension funding difference would be the big part of it. Expense versus funding, I mentioned our funding was only about $20 million. Our expense last year was about $95 million.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, the first thing I had, I wanted to go back to aerospace and the significant jump that you saw in the -- well, not the backlog yet, but hopefully, in terms of contracts that you've won. And I also recognize that you've got a lot of projects in the
componenttext: I guess, the first thing I had, I wanted to go back to aerospace and the significant jump that you saw in the -- well, not the backlog yet, but hopefully, in terms of contracts that you've won. And I also recognize that you've got a lot of projects in the book [ph] that you can't really talk about. To the extent that you can comment, what trends are you seeing in the contracts where you've been winning? And what does it mean for the future of that business?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, George, I think from an, I'll call it, "end market perspective," a good amount of it is DOD. I think we've talked about this in the past. But NASA has been flat to down over a number of years. But I think, as we talked about the last quarter with th
componenttext: Well, George, I think from an, I'll call it, "end market perspective," a good amount of it is DOD. I think we've talked about this in the past. But NASA has been flat to down over a number of years. But I think, as we talked about the last quarter with this new budget in place, the sequestration -- I don't want to say goes away, the sequestration is off the table and there is multiyear ability to fund programs that have been lingering to the side. That's the vast majority of it. When you think about what we do for the DOD, it's everything from satellites to sensors, whether it's optical or antenna-type sensors. So it's a whole mix of those various things. We're quite pleased and proud of our folks, quite candidly, because it's not in any one place, it's not in only satellites or only tactical gear, it's not only in costs plus, it's not only in fixed price, it's kind of a blend of everything. And so I think the portfolio effects of what has been won, but not booked right now, we feel good about. And as I mentioned, we have a whole bunch of other stuff we're chasing down as well.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. John, I mean, I take from your comments that given it's a blend of everything, but you didn't really highlight one or the other. You prefer not to get into that. But if you didn't mind, do you have a kind of a view that you could share with us on ag
componenttext: Okay. John, I mean, I take from your comments that given it's a blend of everything, but you didn't really highlight one or the other. You prefer not to get into that. But if you didn't mind, do you have a kind of a view that you could share with us on again fixed price versus cost plus or antennas versus satellites, et cetera?

componenttext: Yes, a lot of it is classified, George, so I can't. But I would tell you is from a big picture perspective, you have a sense of what the percentages of cost plus versus fixed price. You have a sense of what's our satellite business versus our tactical business versus our services business. It really isn't that different than what has been historical.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Next question I had for you, in terms of CapEx for 2016 and the figure that you cited, from a real world or practical standpoint, how challenging is it right now, or is it, to plan on projects, fund projects, when frankly, you don't know quite how your portfolio will evolve over time for obvious reasons? Can you talk a little bit to that, again, to the extent that you can comment?

componenttext: Well, yes, let me take a first stab at it. George, you raised a fair point, but where we're putting this capital is what we think is long-term good for Ball Corporation going forward. So you talk about Mexico and putting a second line in a little bit later on. You talk about end capacity in Lublin, Poland, increasing end capacity there. You talk about impact extruded of what we're doing, whether it's been in India historically, whether it's in the Czech Republic that we talked about. It's those types of things. And I think if I understand where you're going is, pro forma, any potential Rexam, does that have any impact? And all the things I just laid out, do not.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great, John. That's where I was going with the very clever question. And next question I had for you just on food. And this business has evolved -- food and household -- significantly from the early 1990s. There've been good years and bad years. Ce
componenttext: That's great, John. That's where I was going with the very clever question. And next question I had for you just on food. And this business has evolved -- food and household -- significantly from the early 1990s. There've been good years and bad years. Certainly, you've been cycling through some more challenging years. And I'm guessing because of the growth, especially that you're seeing in aerosol and household, the answer is going to be no to this. But I guess, the question I still have is, has the business gotten, at least some elements of it, to subscale where you don't know that you necessarily have quite the same competitive standing that you might have had? Or would you say, no where Ball Corporation is pretty much as competitive as it's always been in the food business? And if so, why would that be the case?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's just the start. But it's -- recall that every one of our tinplate facilities makes both food can and aerosol. And so if it was just isolated to food can, you'd start to think about scale, but it's not. We view this and we run this business as -
componenttext: No, that's just the start. But it's -- recall that every one of our tinplate facilities makes both food can and aerosol. And so if it was just isolated to food can, you'd start to think about scale, but it's not. We view this and we run this business as -- from a manufacturing footprint perspective as a combined, and we're able to leverage the manufacturing expertise because what we're talking about effectively is 3-piece tinplate containers.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Last one and I'll turn it over. You mentioned -- at least the implications, Brazil should be -- Brazil has been holding up better-than-expected. I forget what you said about the volume outlook for Brazil, I think you said up modestly or moderately f
componenttext: Okay. Last one and I'll turn it over. You mentioned -- at least the implications, Brazil should be -- Brazil has been holding up better-than-expected. I forget what you said about the volume outlook for Brazil, I think you said up modestly or moderately for 2016. We've read some reports where some of the Carnival celebrations have been canceled because of all the economic challenges. My guess is, again, you haven't seen much effect of that in terms of your volume outlook. But to the extent you have color one way or another, we'd be interested in.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I'll just give you a comment. The timing on Carnival will be different. My guess is the Brazilians are still going to celebrate Carnival. So the timing is going to be a little bit earlier. So that will be make the first quarter year-over-year a li
componenttext: I think I'll just give you a comment. The timing on Carnival will be different. My guess is the Brazilians are still going to celebrate Carnival. So the timing is going to be a little bit earlier. So that will be make the first quarter year-over-year a little bit challenging.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, because I think what we're planning for and expecting is post-Carnival, which happens in, what -- 1.5 weeks starts, we'll start to see a seasonal slowdown because that's their autumn. And it will slow down. And as it starts again in the second quarte
componenttext: Yes, because I think what we're planning for and expecting is post-Carnival, which happens in, what -- 1.5 weeks starts, we'll start to see a seasonal slowdown because that's their autumn. And it will slow down. And as it starts again in the second quarter, I think that's what Scott is referring to.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But first quarter, you don't see that much of a challenge or you do? I guess, I wasn't clear on the answer there.
componenttext: Okay. But first quarter, you don't see that much of a challenge or you do? I guess, I wasn't clear on the answer there.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think let me rephrase in another way. I think it's only 4 weeks into the year. But I think in January, we're seeing exactly what we expected. We just know that Carnival is a bit earlier. And much like when you have the Chinese New Year in China when
componenttext: No, I think let me rephrase in another way. I think it's only 4 weeks into the year. But I think in January, we're seeing exactly what we expected. We just know that Carnival is a bit earlier. And much like when you have the Chinese New Year in China when it's earlier or later, it affects before versus after. And so we didn't see a huge run up prior to Carnival, what we saw certainly in line with what our expectations were. The question is what happens after Carnival.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Philip Ng with Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from Philip Ng with Jefferies.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure if you started the asset sale process, but just curious if you're expecting much tax leakage, and when you expect to get your leverage back to your previous targets?
componenttext: I'm not sure if you started the asset sale process, but just curious if you're expecting much tax leakage, and when you expect to get your leverage back to your previous targets?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have pretty active plans in place as to how to minimize the tax leakage. There will be some, but we have, I think, pretty good plans to make it as small as we possibly can. And then, in terms of leverage, we'll have to wait and see until we're done. Bu
componenttext: We have pretty active plans in place as to how to minimize the tax leakage. There will be some, but we have, I think, pretty good plans to make it as small as we possibly can. And then, in terms of leverage, we'll have to wait and see until we're done. But our initial guidance was within 18 to 24 months we'd get leverage back down to pretty comfortable level. And I don't see a big change in that.

componenttext: Yes, time will tell. We're restricted by what we can say. So again, I apologize for that. We can't comment any further.

componenttext: Okay, that's fair enough. And I understand and one of your customers that you're serving in Monterrey, just announced another large brewery on the West Coast of Mexico. Is that an opportunity for you guys? And would you need to add some capacity to meet that demand?

componenttext: I think you mentioned that start-up costs are around $20 million in '15. Can you just help us with how much lapping of start-up costs should benefit 2016 and maybe quantify the impact from Monterrey in 1Q '16?

componenttext: I think the -- they should -- we should start a little bit of a drag in the first quarter and then those start-up costs should diminish quite materially. So our goal in '16 is not to talk about headwinds or tailwinds on too many other things. I hope it's a more normal year. So I think we'll get a little bit more costs in the first quarter. Then after that, we probably won't talk about it very much.

componenttext: Okay, great. That's helpful. And then just on the pricing environment in European bev. There's been some commentary, some country-specific pricing pressure there. Can you give us your thoughts on whether you're seeing this as well? And if you think it's an issue going forward?

componenttext: Nothing out of the ordinary. We're -- we operate in a competitive world. So you always -- in today's world, where the growth is anemic, I think every industry is having pricing pressures, but nothing of note.

componenttext: Okay. And then on the CapEx, you mentioned $400 million this year. And would -- is it fair to say that pretty much all of the first line plus the -- I guess, the original infrastructure and the new Monterrey plant would be in the '15 number? Or is there a lot of carryover into '16? I would assume most of the second line will be in '16. Is that at all fair?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a big chunk that obviously was in '15 that drove the numbers. And then there's still a fair amount of carryover, John talked about the second line coming up here a few months from now. And it's when you spend the money, right? So even though the c
componenttext: There's a big chunk that obviously was in '15 that drove the numbers. And then there's still a fair amount of carryover, John talked about the second line coming up here a few months from now. And it's when you spend the money, right? So even though the capital may -- we may have gotten the plant up and running, it's when you're paying for all those invoices that it shows up. So there's still a decent amount of carryover to '16, and we've got some other projects in '16 that we're working out as well.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question is, I know in the past, you all have, from time to time, talked about penetration, let's say in beer, for example. And my guess is in the U.S., it's somewhere north of 50%. And I'm guessing Brazil is probably approaching 40%.
componenttext: Okay. And then last question is, I know in the past, you all have, from time to time, talked about penetration, let's say in beer, for example. And my guess is in the U.S., it's somewhere north of 50%. And I'm guessing Brazil is probably approaching 40%. If you could update us on that? And then, John, you mentioned that Brazil is now a 50-50 market specialty versus standard. And I know there may be differences of, say, soft drinks. But you -- where do you see the U.S. ultimately settling out in terms of specialty versus standard?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a lot of questions in there. Let me just clarify, our portfolio in Brazil is closer to 50-50. I don't necessarily think the overall market is. But to answer your question about where we think specialty can ultimately end up, specialty continu
componenttext: Yes, there's a lot of questions in there. Let me just clarify, our portfolio in Brazil is closer to 50-50. I don't necessarily think the overall market is. But to answer your question about where we think specialty can ultimately end up, specialty continues to grow and 12-ounce continues to decline in all categories in the United States. Where it will ultimately get to, I can't tell you. I can tell you we're in at about 30% of specialty in North America relative to whole and that continues to grow. And so will it get to 50%? I think it's premature to look out that way. But certainly, the trends are saying it's going to get bigger, not smaller. Even on the beer side of the business, the can penetration, to answer your question there, I don't have the numbers in front of me, but I can tell you that both in the United States and Brazil as well as most other countries, the can continues to take share relative to other substrates. For example, in North America, the overall beer market was up about 1%, cans were up about 2.5%. Down in Brazil, the beer market, I think was down slightly, but the can industry was up, and that was largely driven by beer. So the implication of all that is it continues to take share.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And can you give us any idea of the magnitude of the slowdown you're expecting in China next year?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just qualitatively, as we said, the volumes continues to grow. I know the overall can market in China grew about 5 billion cans in 2015 and the growth continues. Again, similar themes is what I just talked about in North America as well as Brazil that the
componenttext: Just qualitatively, as we said, the volumes continues to grow. I know the overall can market in China grew about 5 billion cans in 2015 and the growth continues. Again, similar themes is what I just talked about in North America as well as Brazil that the can continues to take share from other substrates in the beer segment. The problem is the pricing continues to deteriorate as well. And there's been material deterioration in the pricing over the last 6 months, over the last 18 months. And so, as Scott mentioned in his prepared remarks, that we expect all of our segments results to be up, save for our China business. And that the other thing he said was our cost-out programs have been unable to keep up with the pricing declines. So we are battening down the hatches. We were -- are focusing as much as we can on cost, but we do expect the results there to be down.

componenttext: Okay, okay. Just one on the tax rate. Scott, you got it to 25% for '16. componenttext: All right. Fair enough. I'm just noting this is first time, I mean, you've been asked about it before, but it's the first time you've come out and raised that flag. Second question I had was you did quite a few projects in 2015, adding bev can plants, aerosol, all kinds of stuff. How should we think about the phasing as we work through '16? Or how would we think about quantifying, if it's possible? What the impact will be as you start to get results from that all your hard work?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question. I'll -- as best trying to answer that. When you think about the projects we've talked about even on this call, let's start with Monterrey, Mexico, it started up this month. And so, as you know, there's always a learning curve
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question. I'll -- as best trying to answer that. When you think about the projects we've talked about even on this call, let's start with Monterrey, Mexico, it started up this month. And so, as you know, there's always a learning curve there, and Scott said we'd have a little bit of start-up costs. So I would expect to kind of the typical learning curve and something like this is 3 to 6 months. And so I think, as we get to certainly the second half of the year, maybe even a little second quarter, we'll start to see the benefit of that. And then we're going to get additional leverage as we put the second line on that's going to be starting up kind of second -- late second, early third quarter. So you can hopefully see a trajectory there. In the fourth quarter last year, we started the new line in devices in the U.K. and the impact extruded line. We started up the India plant. Anytime you start a new plant, the learning curve is a little bit longer than just adding existing line or new lines into existing facilities. So I think that devices we feel pretty good about in terms of getting results out of that sooner rather than later. I think the India one is going to be a little bit longer. The Lublin, Poland we talked about that we -- as we continue to ramp up the end production there, we should see some benefit as time goes on. But it does -- it's a ramp-up starting in early '16 as we go forward with that. And we talked about the contour. And in fact I know the last couple of quarters, we talked about the contour bottle as well as the G3. It's on the -- We're making commercially -- commercial product right now. It's on the shelves right now. So we have high expectations as we go into 2016 that you're going to see some momentum there. All of that leads to exactly what Scott was saying that in the first quarter, we still have some start-up costs, and we're really not getting a lot of the benefits, but we're gaining momentum each month we go by in year 2016.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Ball Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Thursday, April 28, 2016. I would now like to turn the confe
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Ball Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Thursday, April 28, 2016. I would now like to turn the conference over to John Hayes, CEO of Ball Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Lyn, and good morning, everyone. This is Ball Corporation's Conference Call regarding the company's first quarter 2016 results. The information provided during this call will contain forward-looking statements. Actual results or outcomes
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Lyn, and good morning, everyone. This is Ball Corporation's Conference Call regarding the company's first quarter 2016 results. The information provided during this call will contain forward-looking statements. Actual results or outcomes may differ materially from those that may be expressed or implied. Some factors that could cause the results or outcomes to differ are in the company's latest 10-K and in other company SEC filings, as well as the company news releases. If you don't already have our earnings release, it's available on our website at ball.com.
Information regarding the use of non-GAAP financial measures may also be found on our website. With regard to Ball's proposed offer for Rexam and consistent with the requirements of the U.K Takeover Code, we will limit our comments regarding the transaction to, number one, what has already been made public via the 2 7 and other public releases ; two, where we are the right letter process; and three, an update of ongoing economic hedging and debt activities relating to the proposed transaction, including the proposed sale of the divestment business.
Also note that there may be limitations regarding the depth of our business commentary and certain other items we would normally discuss on a quarterly earnings conference call due to the nature of the proposed transaction.
Given the nature of our proposed offer, today's issued press release, webcast and conference calls are advertisements and should not be considered a prospectus. Investors should not make any investment decision in relation to the new Ball shares issued in connection with the Rexam transaction, except on the basis of information in the prospectus and the scheme document, which are proposed to be published in due course. This presentation and transcription of comments are not for release in whole or in part in, into or from any jurisdiction where to do so would constitute a violation of the relevant laws of such jurisdiction. For more information on Ball's proposed acquisition of Rexam, visit the offer for Rexam page on ball.com.
Now joining me today on the call is Scott Morrison, our Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. I'll provide a brief overview of our company's performance. Scott will discuss financial and global packaging metrics, and then I'll finish up with comments on our aerospace business and the outlook for the remainder of 2016. 
It's been an incredibly busy start to the year. Our first quarter volumes and results from operations were in line with our expectations. The headwinds from a very competitive pricing environment in China and tough first quarter comparisons in our Food and Household segment, as well a start-up costs from our various capital projects, all that we had mentioned in our January conference call, played out. 
Overall, we are pleased with the performance of our businesses given those headwinds during that seasonally weak quarter, and Scott will go into more detail on the quarter in just a moment. I'll say, however, that other than China, most of these headwinds are behind us and we feel momentum building in our affairs businesses. 
Since late January, we've made notable progress to strategically and operationally position Ball for the future, including signing the agreement for the required sale of the divestment business; producing cans and ends at our new Monterrey Mexico beverage facility; the successful groundbreaking of our aluminum impact extruded aerosol expansion in Velim, Czech Republic, which is expected to come early online in 2017; adding additional customers at our new aluminum impact aerosol facility in India; gaining efficiencies in our new contour bottle line in Connor, Texas and our new tinplate aerosol technology in Chestnut, Tennessee; and growing our aerospace contracted backlog, as well as acquiring wavefront technologies to further enhance our data and capabilities. 
We continue to navigate the highly complex process around the proposed offer for Rexam aerosol while keeping our to focus on things they can control that to day to keep our company strong and well-positioned for future growth. I again want to thank everyone at Ball for rising to the challenge over the past 15 months, and we feel good about the direction of our company, safe for the pricing environment in China with many of the transitory headwind issues now behind us. 
Our future is bright. And irrespective of the Rexam transaction, we see meaningful year-over-year improvement through the balance of the year and beyond. We are right on track and the best is ahead of us. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Scott for a review of our first quarter numbers. Scott?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Ball's comparable diluted earnings per share for the first quarter 2016 were $0.59 versus last year's $0.69. First quarter comparable diluted earnings per share reflected the impact of $7 million in start-up costs related to our sizable Mont
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Ball's comparable diluted earnings per share for the first quarter 2016 were $0.59 versus last year's $0.69. First quarter comparable diluted earnings per share reflected the impact of $7 million in start-up costs related to our sizable Monterrey project and the new tinplate steel project, as well as anticipated lower volumes and our North American food business and competitive pricing in China. 
The first quarter played out exactly as we said in January with the repricing of our contracts in China, challenging comps in our Food and Household products business and the closeout of start-up cost and there's capital projects, resulting in the first quarter being soft. 
Our GAAP results in the first quarter were unfavorable impacted by the economic hedges we put in place to reduce currency, exchange rate exposure, associated with the British pound denominated cash portion of the announced acquisition price for Rexam, and to mitigate exposure to interest-rate changes associated with the anticipated debt issuances, also in connection with the cash portion of this proposed acquisition. These economic hedges allows us to lock in the transactions purchase price economics. Details on these economic hedges are provided in Note 2 of today's earnings release. 
Credit quality and liquidity of the company remains quite solid with comparable EBITDA interest coverage of 5.4x and net debt to comparable EBITDA at 3.3x. Including the noncurrent restricted cash sitting in escrow for the U.S. and Euro bond placements -- from the U.S. and Eur bond placements. The company is that have committed credit and available liquidity on hand to consummate the proposed Rexam transaction and provide ongoing liquidity for the company. 
For a complete summary of first quarter results on a GAAP and non-GAAP basis and details regarding the first quarter, please refer to the note section of today's earnings release, which includes a simplified table format summarizing business consolidation activities. Now moving to operations. Our Metal Beverage Americas and Asia segment comparable operating earnings for the first quarter 2016 were down year-over-year solely due to China pricing, a significant swing in China volume and project start-up costs related to Monterrey. Absent the startup cost in Q1 in North America, this region was up year-over-year. 
As we move through the year, the costs out programs in China will reduce the loss in this region. And despite the China headwinds, we will see year-over-year improvement across the segment in the back half of the year, as our Monterrey Mexico can plant second line comes online and startup cost moderate, more than offsetting the impact of China pricing. 
Segment volumes in the quarter were up approximately 2%, including mid single-digit volume growth in North America, low single-digit volume growth in Brazil and China volumes being down upper single-digits as we proactively prune business to the competitive pricing. 
European beverage comparable earnings were up nicely in the quarter due to aluminum premium tailwinds and strong manufacturing performance, offsetting slightly -- offset slightly by volumes being down low single-digits due exclusively to soft export sales to Africa. In fact, excluding such export sales, volumes in the EU were up low single-digits, in line with overall market. 
Industry demand for specialty can across Europe continues to grow and industry supply/demand remains -- remained balanced. Food and household comparable segment earnings were down in the quarter due to mid single-digit food can volume declines following the prior year benefit of certain volumes related to a past food can customer, inventory holding losses, as well a start-up costs related to our tinplate steel aerosol project in Chestnut Hill, Tennessee. 
We continue executing a disciplined cost control growth equation in the segment with cost out initiatives, like the announced closure of our were 10 West Virginia facility versus incremental investments to support continued metal aerosol growth and production efficiencies, finished gives in Mexico, Europe and India. These decisions will drive future quarter-on-quarter improvement for 2016 and beyond.
In summary, our global packaging businesses continued to be strictly focused on driving EVA dollars from our new capital projects as we get closer to being able to initiate the next exciting stage in our global metal beverage business. 
To employees listening on today's call, thank you for all of the work on all of these projects. Our business is embarking on next transformation, which is so exciting stuff, and the collective efforts of the entire team are critical to our shared success. Now as we look to the remainder of 2016 and the reflecting Ball as a stand-alone company today, there's a snapshot of key metrics, no real changes here. 
We expect free cash flow to be in a similar age as 2015, excluding cash costs related to the Rexam transaction with CapEx expected to be in the range of $400 million and working capital expected to be generally flat year-over-year. Interest expense is expected to be roughly $145 million, excluding the debt financing and other costs, and the full year effective tax rate on comparable earnings is now expected to be in the range of 25%. 
Corporate undistributed is estimated to be in the range of $75 million, a year-over-year reduction of $17 million. And we expect our dividend to remain unchanged from its current level during the proposed acquisition process. 
Exactly as we said in January, in 2016, we expect all our businesses to be up on a full year basis with the exception of China beverage can with momentum accelerating as we move through the year, particularly in the second half. As we indicated back in January and as we look to the successful closing of the Rexam transaction, we plan to focus our comments in terms of cash EPS post close due to the large amount of intangible amortization we expect to record for the Rexam transaction. 
And with that, I'll turn it back to you, John.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Scott. Our aerospace business reported first quarter results of that were relatively flat with last year. Have it I'm happy to report that our contracted backlog was the quarter $100 million higher than year-end and even have a year to repo
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Scott. Our aerospace business reported first quarter results of that were relatively flat with last year. Have it I'm happy to report that our contracted backlog was the quarter $100 million higher than year-end and even have a year to report that as of this we, our airspace backlog stands at greater than $900 million with even more opportunities for growth during the remainder of 2016. 
It's taking a fair amount of patience for us to get to this point, and I want to congratulate the entire aerospace team for their hard work. More exciting, however, is what is in front of us in our space, ramping up all the new contracts and integrating the acquisition of wavefront technologies. 
Now across the company and as we look forward. We are nearing the end of our marathon we began back in February 2015, and we cannot wait to step up to the starting line for the sprint to achieving synergies, cash flow growth and the higher EVA dollar generation that all of our investments can provide. As we said, we continue to face headwinds in our China business, although going forward, it will moderate. We expect all of our other business units to be up year-over-year and feel momentum building in our business. Together, we are working hard to improve Ball in 2016 and beyond, and we look forward to the hard work that lies ahead. 
So with that, Lyn, we're ready for questions.

componenttext: Yes, George, let me talk a bit about China. China is a sore, and there's no hiding from that. It's getting nowhere near attention of the company right now. What I would describe operationally, we continue to drive a hello a lot of cost out of the business in the range of $30 million plus this year alone. The pricing environment is just quite, quite challenging. The only thing I can really say beyond that is strategically, we are assessing and continue to assess how to make this a better business. As you all know, we're not in a business to lose EVA dollars. And so it's a very high focus for us. On the tinplate side, there has been a lot of change in that business. I think the words and West Virginia closure, while unfortunate, allows us to spread a lot of that cutting and coding capability into other facilities. And that's exactly what we're doing. So it's a capacity or rationalization play at the end of the day getting towards our customers.

componenttext: Yes, there's -- the $7 million in that segment is Monterrey. There's also a couple of million on the food side. But in all of the rest of that is really China. The pricing swing from year-over-year, repricing inventory, as you come to the first quarter, so you take up a double hit. And that's why, as we move through the year, the loss will moderate and the cost-out actions start to take hold. And so you'll had  it'll have less of an impact as we move through the year. And then with investments that we're making that come online here, as we move through the year, those will more than offset the China pricing in the second half of the year.

componenttextpreview: Yes. We're starting to go to their seasonally slow period of time. And so we -- as we said in the beginning of the year, we expected modest growth, not necessarily from overall volume, but from share mix relative to glass. And we're still seeing that happ
componenttext: Yes. We're starting to go to their seasonally slow period of time. And so we -- as we said in the beginning of the year, we expected modest growth, not necessarily from overall volume, but from share mix relative to glass. And we're still seeing that happen. As we enter the seasonally slow, we think we're going to get a very modest uplift because of the Olympics. Remember, that's just in Rio. But Rio is a very densely populated area. So I don't think our view for 2016 have changed materially at all from when we are on the call in January.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, with everything going on, I think I want to ask a question about aerospace. You said -- I know on the last call that I think they backlog was like literally, it looks like it's grown to 50%. It was, what, $617 million, now it's over $900 million. An
componenttext: John, with everything going on, I think I want to ask a question about aerospace. You said -- I know on the last call that I think they backlog was like literally, it looks like it's grown to 50%. It was, what, $617 million, now it's over $900 million. And I know you gave us some signs that you thought -- you mentioned of like $800 million in near signed business. And so the question is, have things really kicked in a little bit stronger than you would have expected 3 months ago or 6 months ago for that business in terms of the backlog? And may be you could comment a little bit on the quality of the backlog. What portion is fixed price versus costs plus?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So your first question has anything changed relative to our expectations? The short answer is no. You always have timing issues of when you get signed because some of it is out of your control when you have to have varies government agencies go throu
componenttext: Yes. So your first question has anything changed relative to our expectations? The short answer is no. You always have timing issues of when you get signed because some of it is out of your control when you have to have varies government agencies go through their approval processes. We've had some in the first quarter, some in April, as you heard. And even as we expect going into the June, July, whether it's June, whether it's July, I can't tell you right now. But I know that we still have a fair amount of projects that we call one not booked, which is not in our backlog. But we wanted just we have to go through the signatory process and the funding process with the governments. So nothing has changed on that front. From a mix perspective, I think I talked about this on the January call. There's not an appreciable difference in the mix relative to fix price versus costs plus. It could be a little bit more of cost-plus in the overall scheme of this new business one only because a lot of it is new technology, which I think is good. And our folks have been executing very well on those types of things. So a lot of it is in the DoD, which is both from a satellite perspective, as well as the sensor perspective. And then also, in the NASA side, where we haven't done a tremendous amount of NASA because of their budgets have been so constrained but we've been able to do a very good job or we've are we back into that and are doing several neat things for Nass as we go forward in there.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just a quick one, a follow up is on -- when you look at the guidance items of that Scott gave us whether it's EBITDA, et cetera. headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take this and maybe Scott can chime in. Nothing has changed relative to our expectations. We had said in debt January that we expected the first quarter to be soft given China repricing, given the year-over-year comps in food and household products a
componenttext: I'll take this and maybe Scott can chime in. Nothing has changed relative to our expectations. We had said in debt January that we expected the first quarter to be soft given China repricing, given the year-over-year comps in food and household products and then the startup in the first quarter that, as Scott mentioned a minute ago, will begin to wane as we get into the second quarter and certainly, the second half of the year. So nothing has changed from that perspective. I will say this. It is a bit challenging for us. And I have said this for a year now in our opening comments, that given the U.K Takeover Code, we have certain restrictions on what we can say in terms of profit forecast. And that does create some challenges for us to be able to articulate and communicated a way that we normally would do so. So -- but to answer your question directly into reiterated, nothing has changed from our perspective.

componenttext: Well, I think we're going to lever up here at a close and it's also peak working capital barbering season. So to be a little bit higher. There's always a level of complexity that when you're taking a facility out and having to redistribute volumes, but a lot of it has already been happening because of the performance in Wherton.

componenttext: Yes. No, let's put this in context. They're not expensing delays. They're growing so fast that they can't keep up with their demand. That's what's happening. And so there's a double benefit for as. And so our business is going as fast as they can take them.
