componenttext: Just a couple of questions for you. One, if you could, I hate to keep coming back to the China and the other piece. But if I maybe try to approach it from the perspective of your segment was down, I think, $23 million year-over-year. If you could kind of give us buckets and maybe size them? Is that -- 1/4, 1/3 of that currency is -- I think you said startups were about $7 million. So I'm guessing that's about 1/3 of it. Was China kind of the other bucket? Or how, Scott, would you want us to think about that?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, you had it exactly right. China was the other part of that, both from a pricing standpoint and a volume standpoint. And I mentioned earlier, as you had to lower prices, you had to lower the value of the inventory. So that's why you took a little
componenttext: Yes. No, you had it exactly right. China was the other part of that, both from a pricing standpoint and a volume standpoint. And I mentioned earlier, as you had to lower prices, you had to lower the value of the inventory. So that's why you took a little bit bigger hit in the first quarter than what you'll see as we move through the year. And then the cost-out actions will start -- will continue to gain momentum as we get into the back half of the year. And so for that segment, in total, the back half of the year looks better.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But is it about 1/3 of the delta? Does that sizing sound right? Or am I thinking about it incorrectly?
componenttext: Okay. But is it about 1/3 of the delta? Does that sizing sound right? Or am I thinking about it incorrectly?

componenttextpreview: Yes, your sizing was right. It was roughly $7 million in startup costs.
componenttext: Yes, your sizing was right. It was roughly $7 million in startup costs.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, I thought I -- the reason I'm thinking about it is I thought I heard you mention earlier, too, that you had about $30 million of costs you had taken out in China. And that just sounded like a really, really big number.
componenttext: Okay. Well, I thought I -- the reason I'm thinking about it is I thought I heard you mention earlier, too, that you had about $30 million of costs you had taken out in China. And that just sounded like a really, really big number.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is a big number. That's a full year number. That wasn't for the first quarter. That was for the full year. But as I said, the unfortunate thing is that we've been making a lot of great progress in our North American business and in our South American B
componenttext: It is a big number. That's a full year number. That wasn't for the first quarter. That was for the full year. But as I said, the unfortunate thing is that we've been making a lot of great progress in our North American business and in our South American Brazilian business, and it's being masked by China. That is why I said that, operationally, we're driving the hell out of costs there because we've got to get our costs as low as possible. But then, strategically, we have to assess how we make this a better business.

componenttext: Okay. No, that's very impressive for the kind of the size of the business. If I could switch gears a second and talk a little bit about Mexico. But one of the -- probably the biggest one in the region, I think, you're tied to is experiencing some delays we've read in bringing the brewery up online. How does that or does that change anything with respect to what you're doing in bringing capacity onstream? Do you still provide the cans regardless of who's brewing the beer? Or how does that process work?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, let's put this in context. They're not experiencing delays. They're growing so fast that they can't keep up with their demand. That's what's happening. And so as they build out their existing facility and they've announced a new facility, we are
componenttext: Yes. No, let's put this in context. They're not experiencing delays. They're growing so fast that they can't keep up with their demand. That's what's happening. And so as they build out their existing facility and they've announced a new facility, we are supplying them a significant amount. I forget their growth rates not only as beer, which is very strong. It's a strong -- fastest-growing beer company, I think, in the world right now. But then they are under-weighted to cans. And so there's a double benefit for us. And so our business is going as fast as they can take them.

componenttext: We believe there is, and we'll talk more about that when we can.

componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Dmitra, and good morning, everyone. This is Ball Corporation's conference call regarding the company's second quarter 2016 results.
The information provided during this call will contain forward-looking statements. Actual results or outcomes may differ materially from those that may be expressed or implied. Some factors that could cause the results or outcomes to differ are in the company's latest 10-K and in other company SEC filings, as well as the company news releases. If you don't already have our second quarter earnings release, it's available on our website at ball.com.
Information regarding the pro forma's reference in today's presentation and the use of non-GAAP financial measures may also be found on our website and on today's webcast slides. 
Joining me on the call today is Scott Morrison, our Senior Vice President and CFO. I'll provide a brief of either of our company's performance, Scott will discuss financial and global packaging metrics, and then I'll finish up with comments on our aerospace business. 
In addition, while we normally do not give short-term guidance, given the complexity related to the simultaneous acquisition of Rexam and divestment of those assets required by the various regulatory agencies, as well as the purchase accounting and transaction-related activities related to such, we will be providing more assistance than typical in the outlook over the next couple of years from an earnings and cash flow perspective. In his comments, Scott will give you some visibilities where we are and what we see over the next 18 months at our company. And I'll talk a bit about our aspirations with respect to the earnings and cash flow generation capabilities over the long term.
The momentum in our business is visible from today's earnings release. Our strong second quarter results were operations led. We couldn't be prouder of our team to execute on our existing business while planning for the integration. As we have mentioned on the past couple of conference calls, we expect together earnings momentum as the year went on, and this is exactly what is happening. 
We are strategically and operationally positioned Ball for a multiyear value compounding period of growth on all key financial measures. Now in the second quarter, we began producing cans in our second line in our new Monterrey, Mexico beverage facility, serving our growing customers under long-term contracts. We began production on our new Myanmar facility. We improved operational performance in our food and aerosol business. We grew our aerospace-contracted backlog to over $1 billion. And we closed on the acquisition of Rexam while completing the required sale of the divestment business. Now that's one heck of a first half. The second half and beyond is where the real fun begins. It feels really good to finally have the steering wheel firmly in our grip following 17 months of external oversight and regulatory reviews.
Rest assured that our people executing our integration and valued capture initiatives have skin in the game, and we are all aligned with our fellow shareholders from an EVA and share ownership perspective. 
I'll share more about our exciting future in my closing comments. So Scott will now talk a bit about the second quarter performance, the baseline to work off and some key financial metrics so that the strength and trajectory of our businesses and cash flow can be seen through the fog of purchase and acquisition accounting. Scott?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I'll try to keep this as simple as possible and we ask that the folks following our company aligned with our framework and financial metrics that we're able to provide at this time. i plan to bucket my comments in 3 areas: where we've been,
componenttext:
Thanks, John. I'll try to keep this as simple as possible and we ask that the folks following our company aligned with our framework and financial metrics that we're able to provide at this time. i plan to bucket my comments in 3 areas: where we've been, where we are now and we are we are going. Let me start with where we have been. 
Ball's comparable diluted earnings per share for second quarter 2016 were $1.05 versus last year's $0.89, an 18% increase. Second quarter comparable diluted earnings per share reflects strong year-over-year operational improvement, lower aluminum premiums and a more normal level of corporate costs, partially offset by higher interest cost, a higher share count and the tail end of startup costs related to recently completed projects. 
Our GAAP results for the first half were impacted by transaction-related hedging, purchase accounting and other customer and closing adjustments. Details are provided in Note 2 of today's earnings release and additional information will also be provided in our 10-Q expected to be filed next week. For a complete summary of second quarter results on a GAAP and non-GAAP basis and details regarding the second quarter, please refer to the note section of today's earnings release, which includes a simplified table format summarizing business consolidation activities.
Our model beverage Americas and Asia segment comparable operating earnings for second quarter 2016 were up year-over-year due to solid volumes and operational performance in North America and Brazil and cost-out initiatives in China, which is helping to offset some the impact of price compression in that region. The segment also saw a few million dollars of net start-up costs in the quarter. 
Now that we've computed the legacy capital projects, we do not expect any notable comments on startup cost for the rest the year. Segment volumes in the quarter were up just over 2%, with China volumes being down upper single-digits, as weather impacted demand and we proactively managed our business due to competitive industry pricing in that country.
Americas volumes were up 4.5% in the second quarter and specialty volume continues to grow nicely with specialty being up just over 10% in the first half. European beverage comparable earnings were up nicely in the quarter, due to the final benefit of aluminum premium tailwinds and low single-digit volume growth. The Europe market continues to grow, industry supply/demand remains tight and specialty demand remains strong. 
Food and aerosol comparable segment earnings improved in the quarter due to strong global demand for aerosol containers and improved operational performance, offset by high single-digit food can volume decline due to timing of Midwest pact related to our customer mix.
Initiatives to further improve production efficiencies are on track and set to benefit early 2017 performance. In summary, our global packaging businesses continue to be extremely focused on integrating the new assets, achieving their synergy goals and driving EVA dollars from the recent capital and efficiency projects. Thank you again to all of our global packaging people. 
Now as we speak about our results going forward, we will adjust for and identified all one-time items impacting free cash flow and operating earnings. Things like these associated with a transaction, severance and accelerated compensation payments to special one-time cash payment on the estimated gain on sale, et cetera, so that the underlying strength the business is clear.
Make no mistake, we have a cash machine on our hands. The business we acquired is not fundamentally different than our legacy business. It has great potential to generate cash. In 2016, the free cash flow will be clouded by all the one-off impacts and how much working capital we can squeeze out of the newly combined business in the back half the year. Regardless, we see no deterioration and definite potential in the comparable pro forma business. As we look at where we are now and for the remainder of 2016, we'll start with the baseline.
Using the U.S. pro forma filed in early July and today's reported first half performance, on our last 12 months basis, the business would roughly have been $1.53 billion of comparable EBITDA, which represents $1.1 billion of comparable operating earnings, plus $430 million of depreciation and amortization. This comparable EBITDA excludes amortization of customer-related intangibles of approximately $140 million annually and approximately $60 million of one-time inventory step up. Our baseline adjusted net debt is approximately $7 billion, which takes into account the repayment of Rexam's revolver, private placement and hybrid debt, settlement of derivatives, the U.K. change of control pension payment and the cash payments to the Rexam shareholders. As we think about the second half of 2016, here are some key metrics to keep in mind.
We expect full year 2016 comparable operating earnings just north of $1 billion. And to be clear, our comparable EPS going forward will exclude the amortization associated with acquired customer intangibles, which should be in the range of $70 million for the second half of 2016. Also excluding from comparable EPS would be roughly $60 [ph] million of inventory step up, most of which will occur over the remainder of 2016. The full year weighted average diluted shares outstanding for 2016 will be in the range of 161 million shares, which reflects the half year impact of the 32 million shares issued for the acquisition. For third quarter and fourth quarter, weighted average diluted shares outstanding will be approximately 177 million.
Full year 2016 interest expense will be in the range of $230 million. Given the negative care associate it with a timing of when the acquired revolver, private placement and hybrid debt came out, third quarter interest expense should run about $7 million higher than fourth quarter. The full year effective tax rate for 2016 on comparable earnings is now expected to be in the range of 28%, taking into account the earnings distribution of the combined company going forward.
Corporate undistributed is estimated to be in the range of $105 million for full year 2016, which includes second half incremental cost of approximately $30 million to support the integration from locations such as Milbank, Rexam's formal global headquarters location, which we will exit by December 2016. As we reference in debt reconciliation included in our earnings release, the funded status of acquired pensions was improved by either the change of control payment me to the U.K. pension plan at the closing the transaction. 
With the remainder of 2016, approximately $50 million of pension funding will occur in the U.S. plans. And given the size of the remaining cash transaction-related payments to be made during the remainder of 2016, we do not anticipate a meaningful reduction in net debt by year-end. 
So now, where are we going? As you can view on the reconciliation backup slide provided on our website and based on current operating conditions and FX rates, our preliminary target for 2017 comparable operating earnings is a range of $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion, excluding the effect of approximately $140 million of intangible amortization. 
For 2017, we expect interest expense of approximately $280 million, a 28% effective tax rate, and full year weighted average diluted share count of approximately 177 million. Given that we are just 35 days post-close, our early estimate for full year 2017 free cash flow after $500 million of CapEx is that we'll be in the range of $750 million to $850 million, excluding one-time items related to the transaction, which is a great step towards our goal of free cash flow being in excess of $1 billion by 2019.
And with that, I'll turn it back to you, John.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Scott. Our aerospace business support the second quarter results that were relatively flat with last year. However, I'm happy to report that our contracted backlog closed the quarter at over $1 billion with approximately 70% under cost-plus
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Scott. Our aerospace business support the second quarter results that were relatively flat with last year. However, I'm happy to report that our contracted backlog closed the quarter at over $1 billion with approximately 70% under cost-plus approach and 30% more of a fixed price nature, which provides a good balance going forward. 
We are ramping up and staffing up for all of the new contracts, which will benefit second half in future year's performance. We are excited about the prospects of this business. And politics aside, we have more opportunities for growth assuming the government does not going to any prolonged continuing resolution. 
Now across the company and as we look forward, as Scott mentioned by year-end 2017, we currently believe we should achieve $150 million of synergies for the year and grow our operating earnings even greater than that on the back of our prior capital growth projects and show improvement in all of Ball's businesses. 
While recognizing it is early days in the integration processes, we have more visibilities into the opportunities we thought possible. And while no doubt there will be challenges, we still expect to generate an excess of $300 million of synergies by the end of 2019. 
And as Scott said, you were also tracking towards our goal to grow our comparable annualized free cash flow to an excess of $1 billion. And when our leverage gets to the 3 to 3.5x debt to EBITDA range, we are poised execute a more robust share repurchase program. 
In summary, our company is taking a step change forward as a result of this acquisition. And whether it be in the commercial arena, our cost-out efforts, our supply chain and footprint work, our innovation efforts positioning the can as the most a suitable package in the beverage world and/or any other area, we are going to take our responsibility as a leader seriously. And with our current aspiration of generating $2 billion of comparable EBITDA and in excess of $1 billion of comparable free cash flow by 2019, we see a clear path to growing EVA dollars, which will allow us to double our long-term goal of 10% to 15% comparable diluted earnings per share growth over each in the next several years. 
And with that, Demetra, we're ready for questions.

componenttext: On the LTM EBITDA at the end of 2Q of $1.53 billion and $1.8 billion mid-point for '17, obviously, synergies along should be $150 million based on your parameters. Can you, John, give us some the other assumptions, volume growth by region and also, the benefit from the growth initiatives, Monterrey and Myanmar, and also some the growth that Rexam was also executing upon?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, you're absolutely right when you look at what we have said, there's year-over-year on a relative LTM. We expect $200 million to $300 million more of operating earnings, comparable operating earnings. $150 million of that is from the synergies w
componenttext: Yes. Well, you're absolutely right when you look at what we have said, there's year-over-year on a relative LTM. We expect $200 million to $300 million more of operating earnings, comparable operating earnings. $150 million of that is from the synergies we expect to realize and the balance of it comes from a variety of things. But let's not forget, over the last 18 months to 2 years, we have spent a fair amount of growth capital, whether it's building a new facility in Monterrey, the contrary bottles, Myanmar, Lublin ends, India, impact extruded, our new G3 technology devices or other things, we expect to get the returns on that capital employed. And I think that makes up the back half of that.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to quantify on the volume side. What do you think the various regions would look like?
componenttext: So just to quantify on the volume side. What do you think the various regions would look like?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think let's take a step back and see where the various regions are. The United States, actually, has had 2 quarters as an industry of positive volume growth. We've had a little bit more than that just because of our customer mix and some of the ne
componenttext: Well, I think let's take a step back and see where the various regions are. The United States, actually, has had 2 quarters as an industry of positive volume growth. We've had a little bit more than that just because of our customer mix and some of the new Monterrey facility, which is great. The can continues to win in the United States. I'd say the -- as we hear in the summer months, it's slowed up a little bit over the last month or so, but nothing appreciably. But if you assume flat, let's only flat growth in the United States, that's probably a good parameter. Down in Brazil, it's been relatively flat, don't know that. Ball second because our customer managed fairly well. But we're expecting the second half of this year and going into 2017 to be relatively flat. It could be down a little bit in the second half the year of sir the OpEx have finished up only because the economy is challenged. Europe continues to be growth area. It's up a couple of percent year-to-date, and we respect that. And then when you look at Asia, you have to look at China and as well as Southeast Asia. China continues to grow strong, but we actually have been declining in part because we're trying to rationalize our business not make these cans for practice. Southeast Asia continues to grow mid-to upper single digits. And then in some the newer region so that we're getting our hands around whether at least -- whether it's even Russia, I think Russia is doing regionally okay. The Middle East is a mixed bag. We can talk about what's going on in Turkey. We can talk about the challenges of Egypt as having with their currency, you can talk about some other places. But I think those fundamentals that I just laid out, we don't expect depreciable differences. But I do expect and we do expect, as we go forward, the can's going to continue to do well relative to other substrates.

But as we get further into this year and as we get probably to the January call, we'll give lot more clarity as to what we think the cash flow would look like.

componenttext: Well, I think, if you look at what we've been able to do in our balance sheet, we've been able to get working capital out for a number of years in a row. And while it's way too early to talk about 2019. Being an EDA company, we focus and our balance sheet every day. And so that tends to lead itself to all kinds of opportunities, a lot of which we probably don't see at this point. But I think we have with alignment with the new folks that have joined our company. And it'll be an ongoing process to get after that on a year-over-year basis for the next few years.

componenttext: Well, as I said in my comments, that once we get to 3 to 3.5x range, we will be dedicating our cash flow to a share repurchase program. So by definition in '17, really, it's unclear. It really depends on when we get to those targets. But the sooner we can get to that 3 to 3.5x range, the sooner we'll be buying back our stock.

componenttext: The final question just with the -- still very special incentive plan and then the positive program you weight out in the 8-K earlier in the week. Can you just provide some detail, I guess, on number of people eligible. How deep it will send to the organization? Any details around that will be great.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good questions. 2 programs there. And like I talk about, we all have skin in the game. That's what I was referring to. There's a special incentive program that actually does go pretty deep in the organization, gets into the plant level. It's broad-ba
componenttext: Yes, good questions. 2 programs there. And like I talk about, we all have skin in the game. That's what I was referring to. There's a special incentive program that actually does go pretty deep in the organization, gets into the plant level. It's broad-based, distributed. The measurements are very similar to what we've done in the past that is tried and true. It's based on EVA dollar generation and on free cash flow generation relative to our expectations and what our Board signed up on the acquisition. And so that's a -- it's a 3.5-year program. And it's paid out in stock, which is another important component of that. The second one is the deposit share program. It's a bit more limited for -- we have done a number of these programs, a number 3 or 4 of these over the past 15 years or so. The concept is up to a certain amount by individual, that individual has to buy their own stock. then would get a restricted stock that lapses over a period of time. In this case, I believe it's 4 years so long as they hold onto the existing stock. So you have to put your own money in and then you'll be match up to a certain point. And we think both of those have been serviced very well over the past 15, 20 years. And it's just a reaffirmation that were making sure that we, as people within Ball Corporation are completely aligned with all of our shareholders.

componenttext: Regarding the $150 million synergies by the end of '17, do you have any thoughts on which buckets might be driving those synergies in the next 12, 18 months in terms of procurement, G&A, best practices versus which buckets may be a little bit more back-end weighted? And then in terms of big moving pieces with the synergies, you the identified in the London headquarters closure. Are there other kind of big projects we should think about or the components the synergies?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just preface it by Scots 35 days into a 90-day review. And -- but what I -- you're really getting a kind of a timing issue. And I do think the G&A is more a front-end loaded. You mentioned Mill Bank, which is a good example, which is not imma
componenttext: Well, let me just preface it by Scots 35 days into a 90-day review. And -- but what I -- you're really getting a kind of a timing issue. And I do think the G&A is more a front-end loaded. You mentioned Mill Bank, which is a good example, which is not immaterial at all. From a sourcing perspective, there are certain things we can get after right away. There are some things that we have to wait for contracts to renew. And so that's in process. But whether it's those, whether it's about being more disciplined from a commercial perspective, that's probably a longer-term multiyear game plan. Managing our networks more efficiently effective from where you make/where you ship perspective that we can probably do that more short term or around our overall fixed cost leverage in some of that can be short term. Some of it can be longer-term. I really do think that we are going to be looking at a multiyear year plan. As you all know, but I do think there's some low-hanging fruit upfront. What we aren't going to do is hire an army of accountants to manage what bucket is generating to the million dollars happening where. We're confident that we can reach an excess of $300 million by the end of 2019. And as we said, we're pretty confident that we can get at least $300 million during -- $150 million during 2017.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And then, John, just following up on one of your earlier comments. Rexam had invested in some regions like Middle East, Russia, India, where Ball had chosen not to. And now that you've been able to get a closer look at Rexam's a
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And then, John, just following up on one of your earlier comments. Rexam had invested in some regions like Middle East, Russia, India, where Ball had chosen not to. And now that you've been able to get a closer look at Rexam's assets, I guess, you called them Mercury markets, how would you characterize the return level there? And are there other areas or regions where further capacity had to make sense or alternately you maybe the returns met the Rexam threshold, but not the Ball threshold and you might consider pruning capacity as you have in China?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: We're getting -- we're still getting our hands around that as part of a 90-day program. And some the things have to look at the growth the market and then some the things you have to look at is around risk. And whether it's political risk or economic risk or currency risk, and to some of the areas that we've acquired in that we hadn't been into are actually better than perhaps we thought. Some of them are not as good as we thought. So it is a mixed back. We'll, as we get to October and into our January conference call, we'll have much more visibility and conviction around our point of view on those things. So please, just give us a little bit of time.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on results and closing on the deal the first quarter out. First question I had for you, John. Is there anything that you can relate to us at this juncture about what you might have done differently in your plans that's an opportunity as yo
componenttext: Congratulations on results and closing on the deal the first quarter out. First question I had for you, John. Is there anything that you can relate to us at this juncture about what you might have done differently in your plans that's an opportunity as you bring in the Rexam facilities and vice versa that, in turn, gives you in the comfort in the synergy target that you provided? In the related question I had is on the corporate expense figure that you gave us for on a pro forma basis. Does that figure, do you think once you bring on the U.K. headquarters folks or the -- and in the service is related to that, do you think that figure has opportunity be lessened over time, to be reduced over time? And my last question and I'll turn it over on capital spending of $500 million, is there is some implied -- are there some implied growth projects in that figure that you're not in a position to talk about? Or do you think that's a good number and growth will be additive to that?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me jump on the first one and then I will let have Scott weigh in. In terms of what we're seeing and how we might do things similar or different from the old Rexam, one of the things that I'll point out, we are very excited about the engagement of
componenttext: Yes. Let me jump on the first one and then I will let have Scott weigh in. In terms of what we're seeing and how we might do things similar or different from the old Rexam, one of the things that I'll point out, we are very excited about the engagement of the people that we acquired. I think this has reenergized everyone at our company. But also, our new employees that are coming in. And anyone who runs businesses know that if you have engagement in the people, that is a big chunk of it. So we're very, very excited. When you talk about the assets, you really have to go by region. And so I'll start in South America. They've got some great assets down there. They've got some great people down there. And we're very excited about that. In Europe, they've recently been doing some restructuring in Europe, which is actually helping them there. And I think the asset base there is very good. Obviously, we had to divest our, a majority of our old asset base. But I think the -- on apples-to-apples, it's relatively comparable. In the United States, we think there's opportunity. I think the level of housekeeping, the level of safety, we're going to have to think about putting a little bit of capital and then talking about $3 million to $5 million per plant, not wholesale capital, but to get it up to our standards from a quality perspective, from an efficiency perspective, from our purpose perspective. And then in many other regions that we talked about, many of those assets are relatively new. So while we're getting our hands around that, I think it really more has to do with the question was asked earlier about a risk adjusted return basis what we have done some the things that they had done. And it's -- let's look forward, not back. And we're going to manage these things as best as we possibly can. On the CapEx, and then I'll turn it over to Scott to talk about corporate unallocated. Remember that it's very preliminary. And Scott said the $500 million is a placeholder. What I would tell you is, as we think about it, the CapEx really falls in the 3 or 4 different buckets. Number one, we have level of maintenance CapEx. We always talk about Ball's was $150 million to $175 million. You ought to think probably adding about $50 million to $75 million on to that for the totality of what we acquired. But then, the additional capitals, like we always do and it's tried and true at Ball, is a bottoms up approach and it falls into the 3 of our drive for 10 buckets. It's about, number one, maxing the value, existing value of what we do. I talked a little bit about some of the opportunities we have in North America. It also talks about geographic growth, where as you know, we're just, in the last 12 months, we've started up in Mexico. We started up in Myanmar. There's probably some opportunities there, but we're going to be very judicious about that. And then last, but not least, in terms of new customers and new products, are especially continue to grow very strongly. We've been successful in converting our facilities into specialty containers. Rexam hasn't done nearly as much. And so there's probably opportunities along that path. But that's going to be customer and specific opportunity by opportunity. So that's a holistic context of the way to think about our capital as at least the way we are thinking about our capital going forward. And maybe I'll turn it over to Scott now.

componenttext: Yes, the corporate cost, George, I mentioned $30 million incremental in the second half of the year. So this is kind of a $60 million run rate. But we've got to get through that 90-day review to have a better idea of what that corporate cost looks like on an ongoing basis as we get into '17.

And then we also have continued efficiency gains and other things that the daily life that we do at Ball in terms of improving our business day on day.

componenttext: Yes, well, we probably like you. It sounds like we've heard that there has been discussions about potential capacity additions in that area. There has been a bit of a pause year. We'll have to wait and see what happens if there is new capacity put on. I don't want to speculate at all. But we are very much focused on maximizing the value of what we do down there. We've got a great team. We're very excited about the people there, their knowledge of the business, their knowledge of industry, their knowledge of the customers and their knowledge of the asset base.

componenttext: Well, we're going to look at all the things that we've done over the last number of years, whether it's factoring supply-chain, finance, managing our inventories better, payable terms. Some of them do take time to put in place and that's why I think that will be incremental benefits over a period of time, over a couple the year period. But everything is on the table. That review -- that 90-day review that we talked about is getting into more detail on all of those things. And saying out, okay, what are the opportunities? What are the timing of those opportunities? And then how do they sequence over the next few years?

componenttext: Yes, as you know, we still have a number of one bottle or not booked type of things out there. I think the continuing resolution risk is still out there. And so realistically, it's difficult to assume any meaningful new wins during this election cycle. But we feel really good about the long-term prospects of that business.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then, John, if I could kind of drill into a couple of years within the can business. Maybe if you can talk about Mexico for a second and also talk about China. Within Mexico, it sounds like you had the second lineup and running. I know you built that for 3. I mean, do you feel that how are things going as you sit today? Do you fill that you'll be able to get a third line in there at some point over the next couple of years? And then with respect to China, I know that's been a hotspot where you had some problems. I think you spent some time talk about that last quarter but I think you are going on forwarding suite to work of opportunities to cost up. What perhaps, can be the -- even can be the outcome in China?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, first, with respect to Mexico. Everything in Mexico is going quite well. The volume growth in Mexico that we're seeing, not only for the Mexican market, but for the export out of Mexico is going very, very well. Our customers are doing quite we
componenttext: Yes. Well, first, with respect to Mexico. Everything in Mexico is going quite well. The volume growth in Mexico that we're seeing, not only for the Mexican market, but for the export out of Mexico is going very, very well. Our customers are doing quite well. And so we're excited about that. I'd rather not put specific timing on new capacity in Mexico. But rest assured, the market continues to grow and we think we've aligned ourselves with the right folks down in there. So more to come on that. But it's -- nothing has changed from what we've talked about in prior conference calls around the long-term prospects about Mexico. With respect to China. Probably the same holds true. We are executing very well on our cost out program. Recall in the last call, I talked about in excess of $30 million of cost out, and we are right on track with that. I give our folks a menace amount of credit because without that, it would be a very, very challenging situation in China. The bigger question is, as you look forward, what does that mean? Because you can save your way to prosperity. We think the industry needs a level of consolidation in China market. There's too many independent players out there. The strategic question is how that occurs and when it occurs. And I can't go into detail, but we are taking it very seriously. Because as you look through, there's just from a supply demand perspective, there's too many suppliers chasing too few customers. And every time we -- in the history of our company in the beverage can business, when we see that, it speaks to consolidation. How that looks, when it looks, what it looks like, too early to tell.

componenttext: Yes, it has leveled off a little bit. I do think that the -- when you really look at see is the, we have to think about fountain versus DET versus scans. Found in has been actually the 1 most hit by the declines more recently. BEP it has been doing all bit better than cans. But cans has been holding their own, to your point. The thing that still continues to grow very well is on the Kraft beer side. In our business alone, it's up year-to-date 30%. And as you -- as a consumer, you go out there and you can see cans continue to take a greater share the package mixing the Kraft industry. And then last, but not least, your overall beer category is up -- the overall category itself is up almost 2%, just under 2% and can volume is up over 4%. And so we continue to take share from glass even in some the more mainstream branches or.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from line of Debbie Jones with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously, there's much bigger beverage company, but I know that I think a lot of people are expecting your food and aerosol business to improve looking into 2017. But can you talk about how you feel about the food and aerosol business in your portfoli
componenttext: So obviously, there's much bigger beverage company, but I know that I think a lot of people are expecting your food and aerosol business to improve looking into 2017. But can you talk about how you feel about the food and aerosol business in your portfolio right now and kind the capital you think you're going to need to spent in that business going forward? And then lastly, just kind of a volume trajectory here as we think about there being the idea that there's excess capacity in North America right now specifically on the food can side?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, as I mentioned I think on the last conference call, it's a food and an aerosol business, and those are different end markets. The aerosol business that is actually bigger than the food business, and that's important to note. And we continue to
componenttext: Yes, well, as I mentioned I think on the last conference call, it's a food and an aerosol business, and those are different end markets. The aerosol business that is actually bigger than the food business, and that's important to note. And we continue to see good growth whether it's on the tinplate side. Your North America down in South America, which is. The impact extruded side where we're here in North America and also over in Europe. We continue to see very good supply dynamics -- supply/demand dynamics. We continue to see good growth. We consider -- continue to see good economic opportunities for investment on that side. On the food side, that's where the challenge has been. And it's no secret that there is -- has been overcapacity in there. We've taken our lumps over the last couple of years in that business. Some of it was market related from a pricing perspective. Some of it was self-inflicted related to the cost side. We are 70%, 80% of the way through completing a project that is going to have significant cost reduction in that business to make us more competitive. And that's were I think, Debbie, because of the growth in the aerosol and because the cost out we have in food, that's why we, as well as many other people, do expect a better 2017 relative to 2016. I think longer-term, I just laid out really what the strategies of those 2 different segments is. It's continued to grow with the aerosol and continue to be the supplier of choice for our big multinational customers in the aerosol side. And then the food can side service our existing customers as well as possible and recognizing that's a cash business.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I can just move to the Americas segment. You saw 10% growth in specialty in the quarter. Could you talk about specifically what's driving that? How sustainable it is? And how you think about that when you put the 2 businesses together with Ball and Rex
componenttext: If I can just move to the Americas segment. You saw 10% growth in specialty in the quarter. Could you talk about specifically what's driving that? How sustainable it is? And how you think about that when you put the 2 businesses together with Ball and Rexam?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, gosh, it comes from a variety of things. I'll bottle strategy and bottle technology continues to go well. As Scott mentioned on the CST side, some of the smaller sizes continue to do well. Some of the larger sizes on the beer category continue to go w
componenttext: Oh, gosh, it comes from a variety of things. I'll bottle strategy and bottle technology continues to go well. As Scott mentioned on the CST side, some of the smaller sizes continue to do well. Some of the larger sizes on the beer category continue to go well. Energy drinks, sleek cans, really -- there's not just one area, I think it's across the board Glenna do think, part of our strategy has been, as the 12-ounce declines even throug absolute declines or through cannibalization, we want to grab that cannibalization by having specialty cans. And that -- there's a good chunks of loss of 12-ounce been captured by specialty cans. And that's why we've been focused on it.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is a very broad question. And remember, we're 30, 35 days into this, George. And this is a time of year where you're really not having discussions around price with our customers. And so quite candidly, we've been very much focused on getting our
componenttext: Yes, it is a very broad question. And remember, we're 30, 35 days into this, George. And this is a time of year where you're really not having discussions around price with our customers. And so quite candidly, we've been very much focused on getting our folks aligned over what our strategic objectives are.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. Next question I had, more in terms of the portfolio and strategy. You talked earlier about China and the parallels with other case studies in your time at the company and Ball's development. If an appropriate consolidation opportunity a
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. Next question I had, more in terms of the portfolio and strategy. You talked earlier about China and the parallels with other case studies in your time at the company and Ball's development. If an appropriate consolidation opportunity arose in the next couple of years, do you think you could manage that while also integrating Rexam? Do you have enough depth to manage that? And the related -- well, let me stop there and I had one more question.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, let me remind you that our folks in Asia have been doing a wonderful job in terms of the cost out programs in managing a challenging situation, but they haven't really been affected at all by the Rexam transaction. They have not been involved
componenttext: Okay. Well, let me remind you that our folks in Asia have been doing a wonderful job in terms of the cost out programs in managing a challenging situation, but they haven't really been affected at all by the Rexam transaction. They have not been involved in the integration just because Rexam had no presence over there. And so as we look -- your question is about bandwidth. We're quite cognizant from a corporate perspective of the bandwidth issues. But from a bunch of people on the ground issues over there, we've got a very good team. The biggest question from my -- our perspective, George, on that is one consolidation enough to really change the dynamics. And you've heard us be pretty consistent that we're not just -- we're not going to be investing in China and become the biggest. If there's an opportunity to make us better and meaningfully better as part of that, then we'll evaluate it. But that's the criteria by which we'll look at it.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. The last question I had and again, recognizing this is not the stake in the middle of the play. It's more the vegetables or maybe that dinner roll. Again, in food and household, that's been a business that's been struggling. Again, as you ment
componenttext: Understood. The last question I had and again, recognizing this is not the stake in the middle of the play. It's more the vegetables or maybe that dinner roll. Again, in food and household, that's been a business that's been struggling. Again, as you mentioned, I think to Debbie's question, 2 separate markets, 2 separate sets of dynamics. Does it come a point where the food business, recognizing that you have every intention of improving the performance next year, get such -- so challenged, that it begins to impair your ability to compete in aerosol? Said differently, again using what you said about China, does there come a point is a opportunity perhaps, where combining businesses might make sense in the food market. And I'll leave it there.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, George. We've talked about this in prior quarters. Recall, though, that from a manufacturing footprint perspective, we make tinplate food cans in the same facilities as we make aerosol tinplate. And so when you talk about separating it out, i
componenttext: Yes, thanks, George. We've talked about this in prior quarters. Recall, though, that from a manufacturing footprint perspective, we make tinplate food cans in the same facilities as we make aerosol tinplate. And so when you talk about separating it out, it does become more challenging. But on the flip side of that, that provides a bit, the leverage of that. And so if the food can business continued to decline, we would be taking out a line here, a line there of existing plant. But I don't think you can necessarily separate those 2. But having said that, we don't believe nor do we see exactly what you're talking about. And that's why I said you got to understand who you want. And in that part the business, it's a cash business, so treat it as such.
